title: A Great Read that was Funnier and Deeper than I Expected
content: While not as moving as Trevor Noah‚Äôs Born a Crime or as thought provoking as Travels by Michael Crichton, this is, overall, one of the best memoirs I have read. Smith‚Äôs famous charisma is on full display here and that alone makes it worth a read. But hidden amongst the hilarious tales from his charmed life and the Ted Talk style motivational platitudes are surprisingly honest admissions about his flaws, heartbreaking examinations of domestic abuse and illuminating insights about the joys and horrors of life in an American inner city. The main subject of the book is certainly Smith himself, but like Health Ledger‚Äôs Joker in The Dark Knight, the dominant character is Smith‚Äôs father, a complicated cross between hero and villain. Smith makes his position on his father clear by the end of the book, but I‚Äôm not sure I agree with him or that I could have gone on to a landmark career‚Äîor any career at all‚Äîif I had witnessed someone do those things to my mother. No matter where your opinion falls, the allegory of The Wall will get to you. But that‚Äôs only if you can stop laughing long enough to think about it, which this book makes it hard to do. I know because I‚Äôm still laughing over the story about Melanie Parker and the slippers.

content: 3.75/5.0 Stars I am not much of a nonfiction reader, but this year I decided to give some a chance. A few weeks ago, Dave Grohl released his memoir The Storyteller. That memoir was amazing, so when I saw that Will Smith released one, I quickly went to Amazon and read the preview. I enjoyed what I read and quickly went to the store to pick it up. Sadly, Will didn't live up to the expectations that I had for it and I can't quite put my finger on why. There are times that the story didn't flow. That may be because the book is by Will Smith and Mark Manson. Sometimes I found myself wondering if a part that I was reading was Will or Mark. I don't want to poo poo the book. It is good. If you are a fan of Will Smith (I am a fan) then you will enjoy this. You learn about his life journey and how he became the Will we know. We learn about struggles. We learn about successes. If I could make a recommendation on how to read it, get the audiobook. I cannot say enough great things about the audiobook, but perhaps the best part about it is the fact that when he talks about a song or scene from Fresh Prince, he has the audio clip for it and it isn't just Will reading it. That really added to the story. I cannot recommend the audiobook enough.

title: Beautiful, eclectic set of books
content: Pleasantly surprised by how well designed these two books are. They really ARE an autobiography, just not a typical one. He writes about his life and his loves and his feelings. And those feelings reveal Paul in all of his complexity. In his essays about each song, sometimes he's philosophic, sometimes he's moving -- or angry, quirky, irritating. And sometimes he's really really funny. And there's so much history throughout this book about British and American culture. I bought the Let It Be box set recently and, frankly, have been experiencing buyer's remorse ever since because of its $125 price. But McCartney's massive 2-book set is much better designed and it's filled with beautiful writing, never-before-seen photos, and memorabilia. And it cost half of what I paid for the Let Bet set! It's absolutely a brilliant collection.

title: A revealing look behind the scenes of the Sopranos...
content: There have been tons of Soprano 'gear' since the show ended in 2007 -- books, cookbooks, CDs, podcasts, even calendars and puzzles. But I've found nothing that encompasses the 'whole thing' like WOKE UP THIS MORNING. The revealing, poignant and sometimes hilarious memories of Sopranos' actors Michael Imperiole (Christopher), and Steve Schirripa (Bobby Baccalieri), are augmented by many hours of new interviews with Imperiole, Schirripa, Steve Van Zandt, David Chase, Lorraine Bracco and many others from the Sopranos set. Sharply assembled by long-time journalist Phil Lerman (of America's Most Wanted fame), the book is an unflinching look at the challenges of getting the show on TV in the first place, and how the actors reacted and grew with their roles. Most celebrity interviews usually devolve into he or she 'was a pleasure to work with' platitudes. Not so with WOKE UP, where tensions and laughter on the set share the pages with the ultimate triumph of a show that changed not only television but the creative talents involved.

The only major concern I have with the deck, is the card stock and finish. title: Lots of missed opportunities
content: 1. Art: beautiful, no complaints! 2. Card stock: I read reviews saying that it was crappy, cheap card stock. I‚Äôm actually happy with the card stock. Imagery: some of the cards make so much sense (see pic #1). A lot of the cards just don‚Äôt (see pic #2). Lots of missed opportunities. Why have the gators from Rescuers on Strength, instead of Scar (the lion)? Why have villains from the Sword in the Stone (keyword SWORD), featured in the suit of Wands? For most of the deck, it seemed whoever put them together had very little working knowledge of the tarot, and just slapped random villains on random cards. Some villains are over-used (ie Scar, see pic #3), while others are left out all-together. 4. The deck probably won‚Äôt make sense for a beginner. Unlike the traditional Rider Waite, most of the minor arcana (see pic #4) don‚Äôt have images to help the reader interpret the meaning. They kept the minor super simple, another missed opportunity. I think they could have done SO MUCH with this deck. I hope they come out with another one that isn‚Äôt JUST villains, but utilizes a variety of characters. The idea with villains is cool, but limiting. And I hope they assign someone with knowledge of the tarot to the task!

title: Fantastic read!
content: If you can recount any sort of punk rock glory days, you can probably also recall the constant "sellout tightrope" your favorite band must have tried to walk- how to get their music heard and fill venues without appearing to compromise their values? This book tells the story of several different bands who tried to make the jump from indie to "sellout", and details how that worked out for them. Spoiler: it didn't, often. This book is fascinating even if you aren't familiar with all of the bands included, and if you're a fan of any of them, you'll learn something new. I am a hardcore Green Day/Lookout Records nerd going way back and was aware of what Green Day went through when they left Lookout, but there was a lot detailed here that I didn't know. I came away from reading Jawbreaker's part with an even stronger sense of loss for what might have been- the greatest band the world doesn't (but should) know. If you're a person who enjoys highly detailed, well-written accounts of what goes on behind the scenes when major labels try to make money gambling on what will be The Next Big Thing, you'll really enjoy this deep dive.

title: Nostalgic and thought provoking
content: Sellout by Dan Ozzi is one of the most enjoyable reads I have had in quite some time (within what I think of as "entertainment" reads, ones both about and for my entertainment) while also bringing to light the many conflicting aspects of the overused idea of selling out. As a concept, selling out has a long history. Within music it easily predates punk and within other forms of entertainment, such as sports and writing, it goes back even further. And it is always a questionable idea when applied from the outside, in other words, by fans or journalists catering to those fans. Yet the vast majority of us have used it to discount what some celebrity, individual or collective like a team, has done that we felt went against what we expected. And, as some of the stories in this book show, those artists use the concept to pose as some kind of special entity for their fans, right up until they don't. The thing that makes this book so much fun is that each example is interesting and will take many readers back to that time. So there is that nostalgia fun. There is also the fun that comes from being given the opportunity to think more deeply about an area we often only pretend to give serious thought to, art forms that serve to entertain. Will a reader come away with a more sympathetic and understanding position about their old favorite band that "sold out?" Will the reader think just a bit longer about throwing this particular label on future celebrities that make a move or change that could be interpreted as selling out? Hard to say, the accusation alone offers a form of consolation when we feel left behind by our favorites, so we may well still hurl it. Maybe we will also know in our hearts that things are never quite that simple and clear cut. Reviewed from a copy made available by the publisher via NetGalley.

title: A revealing look behind the scenes of the Sopranos...
content: There have been tons of Soprano 'gear' since the show ended in 2007 -- books, cookbooks, CDs, podcasts, even calendars and puzzles. But I've found nothing that encompasses the 'whole thing' like WOKE UP THIS MORNING. The revealing, poignant and sometimes hilarious memories of Sopranos' actors Michael Imperiole (Christopher), and Steve Schirripa (Bobby Baccalieri), are augmented by many hours of new interviews with Imperiole, Schirripa, Steve Van Zandt, David Chase, Lorraine Bracco and many others from the Sopranos set. Sharply assembled by long-time journalist Phil Lerman (of America's Most Wanted fame), the book is an unflinching look at the challenges of getting the show on TV in the first place, and how the actors reacted and grew with their roles. Most celebrity interviews usually devolve into he or she 'was a pleasure to work with' platitudes. Not so with WOKE UP, where tensions and laughter on the set share the pages with the ultimate triumph of a show that changed not only television but the creative talents involved.
